snippet.title: I chose the Sunshine Coast over a Big Six career
snippet.content: I WAS working as a graduate accountant for Ernst & Young in Brisbane in 1994, when I was sent to work on an audit for a client: Buderim Ginger. I grew up in Noosa and Pomona and was so excited to be back in my old stomping ground. Greg Tuer, the CEO, mentioned that they had a job for a marketing officer going. I threw my hat in the ring and got it. My colleagues in Brisbane thought I was completely mad throwing away a city accounting career with a Big Six firm to move to a regional area. Buderim Ginger sponsored me to go back to university part-time and I completed my marketing subjects at QUT. I had no idea I was meant to be in marketing and innovation but I had found my niche. It was an exciting time for Buderim Ginger. It was in the midst of a strong innovation cycle and I got to be a part of this. We did things like taking the jams and marmalades out of the niche health food aisle in Woolworths and re-positioned the brand in the mainstream jam category. Tony van Alphen was in charge of sales and I was fortunate to have a mentor in marketing consultant Deborah Looseley. I also loved the tourism and worked closely with Joy Varney who ran that part of the business. In 1997, I left Buderim Ginger to go travelling in Europe and ended up staying for nine years, building a career in food and wine. In 2007, I returned with a young family. The lure of home was strong and instead of heading to the city, we decided to go back to the Sunshine Coast and see if it would work. I worked as a consultant for a few years and had some great clients. I met the CEO of Gourmet Garden, Nick White. He was recruiting for a head of marketing and innovation and I applied for the job and was successful. The team at Gourmet Garden like to approach innovation collaboratively and with the consumer at the heart of decision- making. This way of working feels natural to me as I like to bounce ideas off other people: colleagues or consumers. This approach was solidified in our business through our mentor, Dr Sam Buculo, a Professor of Design Innovation at University of Technology Sydney. Thanks to a State Government-funded innovation program, he came to the company to teach us the principles of design-led thinking, where the consumer is at the heart of everything we do. He aligned our approach and as a team we went on to innovate and launch the successful lightly dried herb range in 2014. We are currently piloting a new innovation with chilled finishing drizzles: a range of healthy sauces to drizzle over barbecue meats, made with Queensland-grown herbs and spices, cold blended with olive oil and no nasties. In 2015, motivated by the Sunshine Coast regional development strategy, I co-founded the Food and Agribusiness Network (FAN) with Gourmet Garden colleague Andrew Eves-Brown and Sara Bucher, from Maleny Cheese. FAN is not-for-profit organisation that is about creating connections and facilitating opportunities for its members. This is a voluntary role but is so closely aligned with my day job that it helps Gourmet Garden, too. And, selfishly, I would like to see the Sunshine Coast economy continue to prosper so that my children can have careers here one day, too.
